title: Freshwater snail
text:
Freshwater snails are <a href="gastropod">gastropod</a> <a href="mollusk">mollusk</a>s which live in <a href="fresh%20water">fresh water</a>. There are many different families. They are found throughout the world in various habitats, ranging from ephemeral pools to the largest lakes, and from small seeps and springs to major rivers. The great majority of freshwater gastropods have a <a href="gastropod%20shell">shell</a>, with very few exceptions. Some groups of snails that live in freshwater respire using gills, whereas <a href="Pulmonata">other groups</a> need to reach the surface to breathe air. In addition, some are amphibious and have both gills and a lung (e.g. "<a href="Ampullariidae">Ampullariidae</a>"). Most feed on algae, but many are <a href="detritivore">detritivore</a>s and some are <a href="Filter%20feeding">filter feeders</a>.
According to a 2008 review of the taxonomy, there are about 4,000 species of freshwater <a href="gastropod">gastropod</a>s (3,795-3,972).
At least 33–38 independent <a href="Lineage%20%28evolution%29">lineages</a> of gastropods have successfully colonized freshwater environments. It is not possible to quantify the exact number of these lineages yet, because they have yet to be clarified within the <a href="Cerithioidea">Cerithioidea</a>. From six to eight of these independent lineages occur in <a href="North%20America">North America</a>.

Some of these highlighted families consist entirely of freshwater species, but some of them also contain, or even mainly consist of, marine species.)
Neritimorpha.
The <a href="Neritimorpha">Neritimorpha</a> are a group of primitive "<a href="prosobranch">prosobranch</a>" gilled snails which have a shelly <a href="operculum%20%28gastropod%29">operculum</a>.
Caenogastropoda.
The <a href="Caenogastropoda">Caenogastropoda</a> are a large group of gilled operculate snails, which are largely marine. In freshwater habitats there are ten major families of caenogastropods, as well as several other families of lesser importance:
Heterobranchia.
<a href="Basommatophora">Basommatophora</a>ns are pulmonate or air-breathing aquatic snails, characterized by having their eyes located at the base of their tentacles, rather than at the tips, as in the true land snails <a href="Stylommatophora">Stylommatophora</a>. The majority of basommatophorans have shells that are thin, translucent, and relatively colorless, and all five freshwater basommatophoran families lack an operculum.
As human food.
Several different freshwater snail species are eaten in <a href="Asian%20cuisine">Asian cuisine</a>.
Archaeological investigations in <a href="Guatemala">Guatemala</a> have revealed that the diet of the <a href="Maya%20civilization">Maya</a> of the <a href="Mesoamerican%20chronology">Classic Period</a> (AD 250-900) included freshwater snails.
Aquarium snails.
Freshwater snails are commonly found in aquaria along with tropical fish. Species available vary in different parts of the world. In the United States, commonly available species include <a href="ramshorn%20snail">ramshorn snail</a>s such as "<a href="Planorbella%20duryi">Planorbella duryi</a>", <a href="apple%20snail">apple snail</a>s such as "<a href="Pomacea%20bridgesii">Pomacea bridgesii</a>", the high-spired thiarid <a href="Malaysian%20trumpet%20snail">Malaysian trumpet snail</a>, "Melanoides tuberculata", and several "<a href="Neritina">Neritina</a>" species.
Parasitology.
Freshwater snails are widely known to be hosts in the lifecycles of a variety of human and animal <a href="parasitism">parasites</a>, particularly <a href="trematodes">trematodes</a> or "flukes". Some of these relations for prosobranch snails include "<a href="Oncomelania">Oncomelania</a>" in the family <a href="Pomatiopsidae">Pomatiopsidae</a> as hosts of "<a href="Schistosoma">Schistosoma</a>", and "<a href="Bithynia%20%28gastropod%29">Bithynia</a>", "<a href="Parafossarulus">Parafossarulus</a>" and "<a href="Amnicola">Amnicola</a>" as hosts of "<a href="Opisthorchis">Opisthorchis</a>". " <a href="Thiara">Thiara</a>" and "<a href="Semisulcospira">Semisulcospira</a>" may host "<a href="Paragonimus">Paragonimus</a>". "<a href="Juga%20plicifera">Juga plicifera</a>" may host "<a href="Nanophyetus%20salmincola">Nanophyetus salmincola</a>". Basommatophoran snails are even more widely infected, with many "<a href="Biomphalaria">Biomphalaria</a>" (<a href="Planorbidae">Planorbidae</a>) serving as hosts for "<a href="Schistosoma%20mansoni">Schistosoma mansoni</a>", "<a href="Fasciolopsis">Fasciolopsis</a>" and other parasitic groups. The tiny "<a href="Bulinus">Bulinus</a>" snails are hosts for "<a href="Schistosoma%20haematobium">Schistosoma haematobium</a>". Lymnaeid snails (<a href="Lymnaeidae">Lymnaeidae</a>) serve as hosts for "<a href="Fasciola">Fasciola</a>" and the cerceriae causing <a href="swimmer%27s%20itch">swimmer's itch</a>. The term “<a href="neglected%20tropical%20diseases">neglected tropical diseases</a>” applies to all snail-borne infections, including <a href="schistosomiasis">schistosomiasis</a>, <a href="fascioliasis">fascioliasis</a>, <a href="fasciolopsiasis">fasciolopsiasis</a>, <a href="paragonimiasis">paragonimiasis</a>, <a href="opisthorchiasis">opisthorchiasis</a>, <a href="clonorchiasis">clonorchiasis</a>, and <a href="angiostrongyliasis">angiostrongyliasis</a>.
